bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry Clemons, December 13, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Clemons that the Reed family and Kean were pleased with Hench's recent lecture at the University of Virginia, and were delighted that Hench had loaned some Reed material to Alderman Library.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry Clemons, December 13, 1947
div1.opener:
December 13, 1947
Dr. Harry Clemons
Librarian, Alderman Library
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Doctor Clemons:
div1.p:
I have just returned from a busy Eastern
trip. In Washington, I had a short but very pleasant
visit with General and Mrs. Kean and also with General
and Mrs. Walter Lawrence Reed and a day or two later,
with Mrs. Walter Reed herself and her daughter,
Blossom, in Blue Ridge Summit. They were all interested
in my Charlottesville visit. General Kean especially
asked of you. Interestingly enough, each of these
people had already received newspaper clippings from
friends and seemed quite pleased and satisfied with
these clippings. They were thoroughly delighted that
I had loaned some of the material to your library
and I am glad to feel that they know that I am trying
to use this material properly and that I am, in my talks,
trying to give credit to whom credit is due.
It was indeed nice to see you again.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
